legal_basis: Notice is given under section 1 of the Statistics of Trade Act 1947.
title: Monthly Wages and Salaries Survey

title.text: You are completing this for {ru_name} {conditional_trad_as}

description.text: If the company details or structure have changed contact us on {telephone_number_link} or email {email_link}

list: On average it takes ten minutes to complete once you have collected the information.
Data should relate to all sites in England, Scotland and Wales.
You can provide informed estimates if actual figures are not available.
We will treat your data securely and confidentially.

contents.description: View survey information and questions before you start the survey (this link opens in a new tab)
You will need to indicate each of the pay patterns that are used to pay employees. For example, weekly, fortnightly, calendar monthly, four weekly or five weekly.
You will need the following information for all of your selected pay patterns:
If the last week of the month is affected by holidays please use a more representative week

list: all employees in Great Britain (England, Scotland and Wales), both full and part-time, who received pay in the relevant period
all trainees or apprentices that were paid through your payroll for the relevant period
trainees or apprentices that were not paid through your payroll for the relevant period
employees working abroad unless paid directly from this business’s GB payroll
employees in Northern Ireland
overtime and shift allowance payments
advanced holiday pay
pay award arrears
bonuses or commissions
voluntary employee contributions to, and annual profit from, profit related pay schemes
any redundancy pay and pay in lieu of notice payments
trainees or apprentices that were not paid through your payroll for the relevant period
directors' fees
employer’s National Insurance and contribution to pension schemes
employees working abroad unless paid directly from this business’s GB payroll
signing on fees, for example, sporting professionals
accrued holiday pay
employees in Northern Ireland
benefits employees received through pay, for example, family working tax credit
expenses payments for attending meetings, for example, councillors

contents.description: Calendar monthly, four weekly and five weekly pay

signing on fees, for example, sporting professionals
accrued holiday pay
employees in Northern Ireland
benefits employees received through pay, for example, family working tax credit
expenses payments for attending meetings, for example, councillors

list: performance pay, for example, productivity bonuses
long service awards
appearance money, for example, sporting professionals
trainees on government schemes
directors' fees
employer's National Insurance and contribution to pension schemes
employees working abroad unless paid directly from this business's GB payroll
signing on fees, for example, sporting professionals
payment in lieu of notice
redundancy pay both taxable and non-taxable
accrued holiday pay
employees in Northern Ireland
benefits employees received through pay, for example, family working tax credit
expenses payments for attending meetings, for example, councillors

questions.question: Significant changes to pay or number of employees

list: redundancies
more temporary staff
fewer temporary staff
more overtime
less overtime
pay increase
industrial action
You cannot appeal your selection. Your business was selected to give us a comprehensive view of the UK economy.
The data from your business is essential as it helps us measure the increase of wages over time.

question.title: How frequently are employees paid?
description: You will be asked to provide information for each of the selected pay patterns.

question.title: Are these all of the pay patterns used?

options.label: No, I would like to change the pay patterns
options.value: No, I would like to change the pay patterns

==: No, I would like to change the pay patterns

contents.description: This section covers employees who are paid weekly.

list: the number of weekly paid employees
holiday pay, pay awards and bonuses paid to weekly paid employees
significant changes to the pay or number of weekly paid employees

title.text: What was the number of weekly paid employees paid in the last week of {period_str}?

description: If the last week of the month is affected by holidays please use a more representative week.

list: all employees in Great Britain (England, Scotland and Wales), both full and part-time, who received pay in the relevant period
all trainees or apprentices that were paid through your payroll for the relevant period
trainees or apprentices that were not paid through your payroll for the relevant period
employees working abroad unless paid directly from this business’s GB payroll
employees in Northern Ireland

answers.label: Total number of weekly paid employees

title.text: What was the total gross weekly pay paid to employees in the last week of {period_str}?

advanced holiday pay
pay award arrears

any redundancy pay and pay in lieu of notice payments, taxable and non-taxable

accrued holiday pay

title.text: Of the {answerc50e5990_5933_456a_bdc9_4cc0a02ca02d} paid to weekly paid employees in the last week of {period_str}, what other amounts were paid?

list: performance pay, for example, productivity bonuses
long service awards
appearance money, for example, sporting professionals

answers.label: Holiday pay, paid in advance
Arrears of pay owing to pay awards
Bonuses, commissions or annual profit from profit-related pay schemes

question.title: Did any significant changes occur to the total pay or number of weekly paid employees?

list: redundancies
changes in the number of temporary staff
more or less overtime
new pay rates
industrial action

definitions.title: What we mean by 'a significant change'

contents.description: This is dependent on your own interpretation of whether there has been a significant change in the business’s figures compared with the previous month.
Also consider whether there has been a significant change from the same month in the previous year.

question.title: What were the reasons for the changes to the total pay or number of weekly paid employees?
If your business has new pay rates, what is the percentage increase?

answers.label: Percentage increase of new pay rates
If your figures are backdated, which date did they begin?
What was the number of weekly paid employees who received this new pay rate?

question.title: What were the changes to the total pay or number of weekly paid employees?

answers.label: Comments

contents.description: The next section covers general comments about this survey.

question.title: Please write any additional comments you would like to make on the information you have provided

answers.label: Comments

contents.description: Your response will help inform decision-makers how best to support the UK population and economy at this challenging time.
Learn more about how we use this data (this link opens in a new tab)

submission.title: Check your answers and submit
submission.warning: You must submit this survey to complete it
submission.guidance: You will have the opportunity to view, save or print a copy of your answers after submitting this survey.
